biography.placeOfBirth: Castel San Pietro Terme, Emilia-Romagna, Italy
biography.bio: Luisa Ferida started as a stage actress and first appeared in films with La Freccia d'oro (1935) in a supporting role but because of her photogenic looks and talent as an actress, she soon graduated to leading parts at the end of the thirties. In 1939, whilst working on An Adventure of Salvator Rosa (1939) directed by the celebrated Alessandro Blasetti, she met Osvaldo Valenti. The pair became romantically involved and had a son. Valenti had been linked with many Fascist officials and personalities for years, and this is the reason why he featured on the partisans' hit list. He was finally arrested in Milan, alongside a pregnant Ferida in April 1945. They were both sentenced to be executed and shot immediately in the street.
biography.name: Luisa Ferida

biography.bio: Guido Barbarisi (Rome, January 26, 1889 - Rome, January 16, 1960) was an Italian actor, active in theater and film. He makes his debut at the theater in the early twentieth century with Joseph reciting Sichel, then moving in different companies in the '10s next to Amedeo Chiantoni, Alfredo De Sanctis and Italy Vitaliani. In the decade following is in the Theatre Company of the People's Sabatino Lopez playing with Dina Galli. In 1930 he went to Milan, at the Teatro degli Arcimboldi, which constitutes an own training, first with Franca Dominici and Mario Siletti, then with Dino Falconi. Later passes to the Society direct Za-Bum by Mario Mattioli starring in the show "Wunder Bar". Later he became director of the brothers in the magazine company Schwartz and worked in radio as a director of the Society of Prose EIAR Rome ("Scusate se da sol mi presento", in 1943, with Giulietta Masina, Filogamo Nunzio and Mario Riva, among others). Also he wrote several comedies (including "Jenny, raggio di sole"), some represented by Virgilio Talli. The film starred in a dozen films from 1935 to 1956 as a character. He was married to Dalma Cionci.
biography.name: Guido Barbarisi

biography.bio: After working in the theater for many years, he made his debut in the cinema in 1932 with "L'armata azzurra", one of the first Italian sound film, directed by Gennaro Rulers, and later by "Il dottor Antonio" (1937) and "Ho visto brillare le stelle" (1939) both by Enrico Guazzoni and "Fanfulla da Lodi" by Giulio Antamoro and Carlo Duse (1940); later he played many other films, but in parts of the second floor. In 1936 he married the actress and work-mate Emma Baron, with which will set up several companies to tour both in Italy and in the United States.
biography.name: Ennio Cerlesi

biography.bio: Maurizio D'Ancora was only seventeen when he was spotted by Danish director Alfred Lind who gave him a supporting role in Ragazze non scherzate (1929). But it was with his second movie Rails (1929), directed by Mario Camerini, that success came. Thanks to his good looks, his penetrating eyes and his regular guy airs, he soon imposed himself both on the public and on the critics in movies of fairly good quality (Casta diva (1935) being one of these) and remained very much in demand until the mid-forties. In 1944 he married actress Sandra Ravel, had a son named Maurizio like him, but was unfortunately widowed ten years later. In 1946 Maurizio D'Ancora (whose real name is Rodolfo Gucci) decided to give up acting to join his brothers and devote himself to the famous fashion house Gucci.
biography.name: Maurizio D'Ancora

biography.bio: Emma Baron was born on October 19, 1904 in Treviso, Veneto, Italy as Emma Barbon. She was an actress, known for Two Women (1960), Les mauvais chemins (1961) and David and Goliath (1960). She was married to Ennio Cerlesi. She died on March 7, 1986 in Rome, Lazio, Italy.
biography.name: Emma Baron

biography.bio: Laura Nucci was born on February 26, 1913 in Carrara, Tuscany, Italy as Maria Laura Lodovici. She was an actress, known for I'm Starting from Three (1981), We Still Kill the Old Way (1967) and Colpire al cuore (1982). She died on January 30, 1994 in Rome, Lazio, Italy.
biography.name: Laura Nucci

biography.bio: Luigi Pavese was born on October 25, 1896 in Asti, Piedmont, Italy. He is known for his work on Sur la piste de l'Ouest sauvage (1965), Antonio Meucci (1940) and La porta (1964). He died on December 13, 1969 in Rome, Lazio, Italy.
biography.name: Luigi Pavese

biography.bio: Augusto Marcacci was born on June 4, 1892 in Florence, Tuscany, Italy. He is known for his work on La sposa dei re (1938), Le vie del cuore (1942) and Dimmed Lights (1936). He died on December 7, 1969 in Rome, Lazio, Italy.
biography.name: Augusto Marcacci

biography.bio: Enzo Gainotti was born on May 7, 1892 in Parma, Emilia-Romagna, Italy. He was an actor, known for Thirty Seconds of Love (1936), Ti conosco, mascherina! (1943) and The Little School Mistress (1934). He died on September 4, 1962 in Brescello, Emilia-Romagna.
biography.name: Enzo Gainotti

biography.bio: Vanna Vanni was born on January 7, 1920 in Rome, Lazio, Italy as Maria Angelica Giovanna Pegna. She was an actress, known for Un marito per il mese di aprile (1941), 4 ragazze sognano (1943) and Le educande di Saint-Cyr (1939). She died on March 6, 1998.
biography.name: Vanna Vanni

biography.bio: Giorgio Piamonti is an actor, known for La prigione (1944), Freccia d'oro (1935) and Le Tyran de Padoue (1946).
biography.name: Giorgio Piamonti

biography.bio: Bruno Smith is an actor, known for The Last Roll-Call (1936), Kean: Genius or Scoundrel (1957) and The Spy with Ten Faces (1966).
biography.name: Bruno Smith

biography.bio: Giorgio Capecchi (Livorno, August 7, 1902 - Rome, 29 August 1978) was an Italian actor and dubber. Stage and film actor of excellent preparation and culture, elder brother of the baritone Renato, debuted in theaters facing not only very young character roles, despite the remarkable temperament that could also allow the most important parts. A little balding, thin, with warm vocal and well set up, after starring on the radio, is dedicated to becoming one of the historic dubbing voices of the second generation of dubbing. A real star, who gave his voice from deep tones to large foreign actors, both characteristics, such as Louis Calhern, Eduardo Ciannelli, Karl Malden, George O'Brien, who first actors such as Charles Laughton, Jack Palance, Broderick Crawford, Edward G. Robinson, Orson Welles, Spencer Tracy and many others. He was also very active in the animated Disney film, playing the Mr. Lock in "Alice in Wonderland" (1951), Benjamin Franklin in "Ben and Me" (1953), King Hubert in "Sleeping Beauty" (1959), the the colonel in "One Hundred and One Dalmatians" (1961), Sir Hector in "The Sword in the Stone" (1963) and botheration in "Winnie the Pooh and the Honey Tree" (1966).
biography.name: Giorgio Capecchi

biography.bio: Nane Chaubert is an actress, known for Freccia d'oro (1935), Quelle drôle de gosse! (1935) and La route heureuse (1936).
biography.name: Nane Chaubert

biography.bio: Cesare Polacco was born on May 14, 1900 in Venice, Veneto, Italy. He is known for his work on L'escadron blanc (1936), Arènes en folie (1948) and Il leone di San Marco (1969). He was married to Clelia Bernacchi. He died on March 2, 1986 in Rome, Lazio, Italy.
biography.name: Cesare Polacco
